PROCEDURE IN DETAIL After the successful induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed (confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location).
Patient Position: Supine

Initial Airway Inspection Findings: The laryngeal mask airway (LMA) is in good position.
Pharynx: Not assessed due to bronchoscopy introduction through LMA.

Larynx: Normal.

Vocal Cords: Tissue/web at anterior commissure.
Trachea: exophytic endobronchial mass with mixed extrinsic compression at distal trachea, Left side.

Main Carina: Sharp.
Left Lung Proximal Airways: Obstructed airways at LUL and distal mainstem secondary to tumor compression.
Right Lung Proximal Airways: Normal anatomic branching to segmental level. No evidence of mass, lesions, bleeding or other endobronchial pathology.
Mucosa: Erythematous and Friable.

Secretions: Minimal, thin, and clear mucus. Blood at the bronchus intermedius and distal Left-sided airways.
Therapeutic Aspiration Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the Trachea (Distal 1/3), Left Mainstem, and lobar segments.
Endobronchial Tumor Excision Endobronchial tumor was noted and excised with mechanical debridement using forceps.
Note: Bleeding/oozing was noted from the airways so the decision was made to intubate the patient with an endotracheal tube.
Anesthesia placed 8.0mm ETT without issue.

Endobronchial Tumor Destruction Endobronchial obstruction at the LUL and distal mainstem was treated with the following modalities:

Mechanical: Forceps used for tissue/tumor debulking.
APC: 1.5mm apical probe (Forced, effect 3) used for tissue/tumor debulking and hemostasis.
Cryoprobe: 1.9mm Cryoprobe (5-15 second applications) used for tissue/tumor debulking and hemostasis.
Prior to treatment, affected airway was noted to be 10% patent. After treatment, the airway was 50% patent.
Hemostasis Endobronchial hemostasis was achieved. Bleeding/oozing was treated with cold saline and TXA (500mg).
The patient tolerated the procedure well. There were no immediate complications.
At the conclusion of the operation, the patient was extubated in the operating room and transported to the recovery room in stable condition.
SPECIMENS

None

IMPRESSION / PLAN

Patient was noted to have extensive endobronchial tumor involvement at the Left-sided airways.
This was treated with multiple modalities including forceps, APC, and cryotherapy.
At the conclusion of the case patent distal Left-sided airways were identified.

Post procedure CXR.

Continued care per primary team.
If patient has scant hemoptysis, would treat with TXA 250mg NEB PRN.

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL After the successful induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed (confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location).
Patient Position: Supine

Initial Airway Inspection Findings: The laryngeal mask airway (LMA) is in good position.
Pharynx: Not assessed due to bronchoscopy introduction through LMA.

Larynx: Normal.

Vocal Cords: Tissue/web at anterior commissure.
Trachea: extrinsic compression from tumor as well as some extruding tumor at distal trachea, Left side.

Main Carina: Sharp.
Left Lung Proximal Airways: Obstructed airways at LUL and distal mainstem secondary to tumor compression.
Right Lung Proximal Airways: Normal anatomic branching to segmental level. No evidence of mass, lesions, bleeding or other endobronchial pathology.
Mucosa: Erythematous and Friable.

Secretions: Minimal, thin, and clear mucus. Blood at the bronchus intermedius and distal Left-sided airways.
Therapeutic Aspiration Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the Trachea (Distal 1/3), Left Mainstem, and lobar segments.
Endobronchial Tumor Excision Endobronchial tumor was noted and excised with mechanical debridement using forceps.
Note: Bleeding/oozing was noted from the airways so the decision was made to intubate the patient with an endotracheal tube.
Anesthesia placed 8.0mm ETT without issue.

Endobronchial Tumor Destruction Endobronchial obstruction at the LUL and distal mainstem was treated with the following modalities:

Mechanical: Forceps used for tissue/tumor debulking.
APC: 1.5mm apical probe (Forced, effect 3) used for tissue/tumor debulking and hemostasis.
Cryoprobe: 2.4mm Cryoprobe (3-10 second applications) used for tissue/tumor debulking and hemostasis.
Prior to treatment, affected airway was noted to be 5% patent. After treatment, the airway was 15% patent.
Hemostasis Endobronchial hemostasis was achieved. Bleeding/oozing was treated with cold saline, TXA (total 1000mg), and epinephrine (total 1000mg).
The patient tolerated the procedure well. There were no immediate complications.
At the conclusion of the operation, the patient was extubated in the operating room and transported to the recovery room in stable condition.

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL After the successful induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed (confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location).
Patient Position: Supine

Initial Airway Inspection Findings: The laryngeal mask airway (LMA) is in good position.
Pharynx: Not assessed due to bronchoscopy introduction through LMA.

Larynx: Normal.

Vocal Cords: Tissue/web at anterior commissure.
Trachea: exophytic endobronchial mass with mixed extrinsic compression at distal trachea, Left side.

Main Carina: Sharp.
Left Lung Proximal Airways: Obstructed airways at LUL and distal mainstem secondary to tumor compression.
Right Lung Proximal Airways: Normal anatomic branching to segmental level. No evidence of mass, lesions, bleeding or other endobronchial pathology.
Mucosa: Erythematous and Friable.

Secretions: Minimal, thin, and clear mucus. Blood at the bronchus intermedius and distal Left-sided airways.
Therapeutic Aspiration Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the Trachea (Distal 1/3), Left Mainstem, and lobar segments.
Endobronchial Tumor Excision Endobronchial tumor was noted and excised with mechanical debridement using forceps.
Note: Bleeding/oozing was noted from the airways so the decision was made to intubate the patient with an endotracheal tube.
Anesthesia placed 8.0mm ETT without issue.

Endobronchial Tumor Destruction Endobronchial obstruction at the LUL and distal mainstem was treated with the following modalities:

Mechanical: Forceps used for tissue/tumor debulking.
APC: 2.3mm Straightfire probe (Forced, effect 3) used for tissue/tumor debulking and hemostasis.
Cryoprobe: 2.4mm Cryoprobe (3-10 second applications) used for tissue/tumor debulking and hemostasis.
Prior to treatment, affected airway was noted to be 5% patent. After treatment, the airway was 60% patent.
Hemostasis Endobronchial hemostasis was achieved. Bleeding/oozing was treated with cold saline and dilute epinephrine.
The patient tolerated the procedure well. There were no immediate complications.
At the conclusion of the operation, the patient was extubated in the operating room and transported to the recovery room in stable condition.

31645 Therapeutic aspiration initial episode

31640 Bronchoscopy with excision

31641 Destruction of tumor OR relief of stenosis by any method other than excision (eg. laser therapy, cryotherapy)

Modifier 22 Details: Unusual Procedure.
This patient required multiple modalities for debulking and to treat bronchial stenosis.
This resulted in >100% increased work due to Increased intensity, Time, Technical difficulty of procedure, and Physical and mental effort required.
Apply to: 31640 Bronchoscopy with excision; 31641 Destruction of tumor OR relief of stenosis.
ATTENDING [REDACTED]

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL After the successful induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed (confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location).
Patient Position: Supine

Initial Airway Inspection Findings: The laryngeal mask airway (LMA) is in good position.
Pharynx: Not assessed due to bronchoscopy introduction through LMA.

Larynx: Normal.

Vocal Cords: Tissue/web at anterior commissure.
Trachea: extrinsic compression from tumor as well as some extruding tumor at distal trachea, Right side.

Main Carina: Sharp.
Right Lung Proximal Airways: Obstructed airways at RUL and bronchus intermedius secondary to tumor compression.
Left Lung Proximal Airways: Normal anatomic branching to segmental level. No evidence of mass, lesions, bleeding or other endobronchial pathology.
Mucosa: Erythematous and Friable.

Secretions: Minimal, thin, and clear mucus. Blood at the bronchus intermedius and distal Right-sided airways.
Therapeutic Aspiration Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the Trachea (Distal 1/3), Right Mainstem, and lobar segments.
Endobronchial Tumor Excision Endobronchial tumor was noted and excised with mechanical debridement using forceps.
Note: Bleeding/oozing was noted from the airways so the decision was made to intubate the patient with an endotracheal tube.
Anesthesia placed 8.0mm ETT without issue.

Endobronchial Tumor Destruction Endobronchial obstruction at the RUL and bronchus intermedius was treated with the following modalities:

Mechanical: Forceps used for tissue/tumor debulking.
APC: 2.3mm Straightfire probe (Forced, effect 3) used for tissue/tumor debulking and hemostasis.
Cryoprobe: 1.9mm Cryoprobe (5-15 second applications) used for tissue/tumor debulking and hemostasis.
Prior to treatment, affected airway was noted to be 10% patent. After treatment, the airway was 50% patent.
Hemostasis Endobronchial hemostasis was achieved. Bleeding/oozing was treated with cold saline, TXA (total 1000mg), and epinephrine (total 1000mg).
The patient tolerated the procedure well. There were no immediate complications.
At the conclusion of the operation, the patient was extubated in the operating room and transported to the recovery room in stable condition.
SPECIMENS

None

IMPRESSION / PLAN

[REDACTED] is a 85-year-old female who presents for bronchoscopy for evaluation of recurrent tumor ingrowth.
Patient was noted to have extensive endobronchial tumor involvement at the Right-sided airways.
This was treated with multiple modalities including forceps, APC, and cryotherapy.
At the conclusion of the case patent distal Right-sided airways were identified.

Post procedure CXR.

Continued care per primary team.
If patient has scant hemoptysis, would treat with TXA 500mg NEB Q8h.

Note: Bleeding/oozing was noted from the airways so the decision was made to intubate the patient with an endotracheal tube.

Mechanical: Forceps used for tissue/tumor debulking.
APC: 2.3mm Straightfire probe (Forced, effect 3) used for tissue/tumor debulking and hemostasis.
Cryoprobe: 1.9mm Cryoprobe (3-10 second applications) used for tissue/tumor debulking and hemostasis.

Hemostasis Endobronchial hemostasis was achieved. Bleeding/oozing was treated with cold saline, TXA (total 1000mg), and epinephrine (total 1000mg).
The patient tolerated the procedure well. There were no immediate complications.
At the conclusion of the operation, the patient was extubated in the operating room and transported to the recovery room in stable condition.

31645 Therapeutic aspiration initial episode

31640 Bronchoscopy with excision

31641 Destruction of tumor OR relief of stenosis by any method other than excision (eg. laser therapy, cryotherapy)

Modifier 22 Details: Unusual Procedure.
This patient required multiple modalities for debulking and to treat bronchial stenosis.

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL After the successful induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed (confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location).
Patient Position: Supine

Initial Airway Inspection Findings: The laryngeal mask airway (LMA) is in good position.
Pharynx: Not assessed due to bronchoscopy introduction through LMA.

Larynx: Normal.

Vocal Cords: Tissue/web at anterior commissure.
Trachea: exophytic endobronchial mass with mixed extrinsic compression at distal trachea, Right side.

Main Carina: Sharp.
Right Lung Proximal Airways: Obstructed airways at RUL and bronchus intermedius secondary to tumor compression.
Left Lung Proximal Airways: Normal anatomic branching to segmental level. No evidence of mass, lesions, bleeding or other endobronchial pathology.
Mucosa: Erythematous and Friable.

Secretions: Minimal, thin, and clear mucus. Blood at the bronchus intermedius and distal Right-sided airways.
Therapeutic Aspiration Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the Trachea (Distal 1/3), Right Mainstem, and lobar segments.
Endobronchial Tumor Excision Endobronchial tumor was noted and excised with mechanical debridement using forceps.
Note: Bleeding/oozing was noted from the airways so the decision was made to intubate the patient with an endotracheal tube.
Anesthesia placed 8.0mm ETT without issue.

Endobronchial Tumor Destruction Endobronchial obstruction at the RUL and bronchus intermedius was treated with the following modalities:

Mechanical: Forceps used for tissue/tumor debulking.
APC: 2.3mm Straightfire probe (Forced, effect 3) used for tissue/tumor debulking and hemostasis.
Cryoprobe: 1.9mm Cryoprobe (10-20 second applications) used for tissue/tumor debulking and hemostasis.
Prior to treatment, affected airway was noted to be 20% patent. After treatment, the airway was 80% patent.
Hemostasis Endobronchial hemostasis was achieved. Bleeding/oozing was treated with cold saline, TXA (total 1000mg), and epinephrine (total 1000mg).
The patient tolerated the procedure well. There were no immediate complications.
At the conclusion of the operation, the patient was extubated in the operating room and transported to the recovery room in stable condition.
SPECIMENS

None

IMPRESSION / PLAN

[REDACTED] is a 82-year-old female who presents for bronchoscopy for evaluation of airway stenosis.
Patient was noted to have extensive endobronchial tumor involvement at the Right-sided airways.
This was treated with multiple modalities including forceps, APC, and cryotherapy.
At the conclusion of the case patent distal Right-sided airways were identified.

Post procedure CXR.

Continued care per primary team.
If patient has scant hemoptysis, would treat with TXA 500mg NEB Q8h.

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL After the successful induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed (confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location).
Patient Position: Supine

Initial Airway Inspection Findings: The laryngeal mask airway (LMA) is in good position.
Pharynx: Not assessed due to bronchoscopy introduction through LMA.

Larynx: Normal.

Vocal Cords: Tissue/web at anterior commissure.
Trachea: exophytic endobronchial mass with mixed extrinsic compression at distal trachea, Right side.

Main Carina: Sharp.
Right Lung Proximal Airways: Obstructed airways at RUL and bronchus intermedius secondary to tumor compression.
Left Lung Proximal Airways: Normal anatomic branching to segmental level. No evidence of mass, lesions, bleeding or other endobronchial pathology.
Mucosa: Erythematous and Friable.

Secretions: Minimal, thin, and clear mucus. Blood at the bronchus intermedius and distal Right-sided airways.
Therapeutic Aspiration Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the Trachea (Distal 1/3), Right Mainstem, and lobar segments.
Endobronchial Tumor Excision Endobronchial tumor was noted and excised with mechanical debridement using forceps.
Note: Bleeding/oozing was noted from the airways so the decision was made to intubate the patient with an endotracheal tube.
Anesthesia placed 8.0mm ETT without issue.

Endobronchial Tumor Destruction Endobronchial obstruction at the RUL and bronchus intermedius was treated with the following modalities:

Mechanical: Forceps used for tissue/tumor debulking.
APC: Side-fire probe (Forced, effect 3) used for tissue/tumor debulking and hemostasis.
Cryoprobe: 1.9mm Cryoprobe (10-20 second applications) used for tissue/tumor debulking and hemostasis.
Prior to treatment, affected airway was noted to be 5% patent. After treatment, the airway was 15% patent.
Hemostasis Endobronchial hemostasis was achieved. Bleeding/oozing was treated with cold saline, TXA (total 1000mg), and epinephrine (total 1000mg).
The patient tolerated the procedure well. There were no immediate complications.
At the conclusion of the operation, the patient was extubated in the operating room and transported to the recovery room in stable condition.

Right Lung Proximal Airways: Obstructed airways at RUL and bronchus intermedius secondary to tumor compression.
Left Lung Proximal Airways: Normal anatomic branching to segmental level. No evidence of mass, lesions, bleeding or other endobronchial pathology.
Mucosa: Erythematous and Friable.

Secretions: Minimal, thin, and clear mucus. Blood at the bronchus intermedius and distal Right-sided airways.
Therapeutic Aspiration Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the Trachea (Distal 1/3), Right Mainstem, and lobar segments.
Endobronchial Tumor Excision Endobronchial tumor was noted and excised with mechanical debridement using forceps.
Note: Bleeding/oozing was noted from the airways so the decision was made to intubate the patient with an endotracheal tube.
Anesthesia placed 8.0mm ETT without issue.

Endobronchial Tumor Destruction Endobronchial obstruction at the RUL and bronchus intermedius was treated with the following modalities:

Mechanical: Forceps used for tissue/tumor debulking.
APC: 2.3mm Straightfire probe (Forced, effect 3) used for tissue/tumor debulking and hemostasis.
Cryoprobe: 2.4mm Cryoprobe (5-15 second applications) used for tissue/tumor debulking and hemostasis.
Prior to treatment, affected airway was noted to be 10% patent. After treatment, the airway was 50% patent.
Hemostasis Endobronchial hemostasis was achieved. Bleeding/oozing was treated with cold saline, TXA (total 1000mg), and epinephrine (total 1000mg).
The patient tolerated the procedure well. There were no immediate complications.
At the conclusion of the operation, the patient was extubated in the operating room and transported to the recovery room in stable condition.
SPECIMENS

None

IMPRESSION / PLAN

[REDACTED] is a 71-year-old male who presents for bronchoscopy for evaluation of malignant airway obstruction.
Patient was noted to have extensive endobronchial tumor involvement at the Right-sided airways.
This was treated with multiple modalities including forceps, APC, and cryotherapy.
At the conclusion of the case patent distal Right-sided airways were identified.
